title: Dalton-in-Furness Walks

images.title: Chris Downer, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dalton Castle is a 14th-century peel tower and in the ownership of the National Trust. Previously, Furness Abbey's manorial court was located in the castle. Here, the abbot exercised his authority under the abbey's foundation charter from 1127 to hold manorial courts and administer justice throughout the lordship of Furness.

images.title: Low sandstone wall at Abbots Wood Garden by Stephen Middlemiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Low sandstone wall at Abbots Wood Garden

images.title: Sandstone arches in Furness Abbey by Stephen Middlemiss, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sandstone arches in Furness Abbey

description: This Cumbrian town lies just to the north of Barrow in Furness and just a few miles from the coast. Local walking highlights include the wildlife rich Sandscale Haws National Nature Reserve and the long distance Cistercian Way which runs through the town. This walk takes you along a section of the Way to visit two of the significant local historical sites. You'll pass the 14th century Dalton Castle before following country trails south to the Abbotswood Nature Reserve and Furness Abbey. Here you can enjoy a stroll around the grounds of the photogenic abbey ruins which dates back to the 12th century. Dalton castle is owned by the National Trust and includes the old courtroom and gaol. You can explore the ancient building and learn all about its history from the knowledgeable guides. The castle has strong links to the nearby Furness Abbey so the walk ties these two signficant sites together very nicely.
